prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Preference of parties

para.paratext: The Panel will not be bound by the preference of the parties for a particular transferee court. Nonetheless, the Panel will consider the parties' preferences in selecting a transferee court and will give their preferences some weight.[1] The Panel may consider both the district most favored by the parties or the parties' first and second choices.[2] The extent of support for a particular forum need not be unanimous, enthusiastic support. The Panel has relied on parties “acquiescing” in a particular forum,[3] or merely that it is “unopposed.”[4] The agreement of many, but not all, parties is relevant.[5] The Panel has noted and apparently given some weight to the choice of the parties “in the alternative,” referring either to second or third choice districts or the choice of district of parties objecting to any transfer.[6] Of course, unanimous support for one district will carry significant weight.[7] If the best can be said is that “some” parties support a forum, the Panel may find that noteworthy.[8] One suspects that weak support of the parties is not likely to be a compelling factor, even if mentioned as relevant.

In a case involving eight actions pending in six districts in which the Panel determined that four potential transferee courts would be appropriate transferee courts, the Panel selected one district because it was either the first or second choice of all the litigants.[9] If all the parties agree on a transferee district the Panel will give the choice special consideration.[10] In one case the Panel noted that the agreement of the parties on not only transfer, but also on a transferee district, made its decision “an easy one.”[11]

The Panel will also give consideration to preference of parties reflected in matters not directly before the Panel. For example, the Panel in one case considered and apparently gave weight to the fact that some parties had stipulated to transfer of their actions to one of the potential transferee districts.[12] Similarly, the Panel has looked to the fact that large numbers of parties had opted in to a Fair Labor Standards Act collective action.[13]

The Panel gives little consideration to arguments for transfer to “my district” in the absence of specific reasons supporting that result. The Panel has described such arguments as “parochial.”[14] The Panel also has also determined that the parties' heated disagreement over the choice of a transferee forum would support transfer to an entirely different district.[15] Despite the willingness to consider the views of the parties, the Panel will, in appropriate cases, centralize litigation in a district suggested by none of the parties.[16]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index Manipulation Antitrust Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (choice of many parties on both sides of the “v”); In re Iron Oak Technologies, LLC, Patent Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 3d 1371 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (transfer to district all parties support); In re Monat Hair Care Products Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 3d 1364 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (many parties favored district); In re Facebook, Inc., Consumer Privacy User Profile Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 3d 1362 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (same); In re Restasis (Cyclosporine Ophthalmic Emulsion) Antitrust Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1332 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (agreeable to many parties); In re: Equifax, Inc., Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1322 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (support by defendants and vast majority of plaintiffs); In re Jiffy Lube International, Inc., Text Spam Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Greenwood Credit Union Prescreening Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1352, 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (transfer to “unopposed choice of movant”); In re Aqua Dots Products Liability Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer to district all parties agree on); In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits “ERISA” Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Sony BMG Audio Compact Disc Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc., Oil Filter Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Bank of America ATM Fee Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Elevator and Escalator Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re High Sulfur Content Gasoline Products Liability Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 2d 755 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Publication Paper Antitrust Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re General Motors Corp. Dex-Cool Products Liability Litigation, 293 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re IDT Corp. Calling Card Terms Litigation, 278 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re South African Apartheid Litigation, 238 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) Antitrust Litigation, 228 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (noting that majority of parties on both sides of case favor transferee district); In re America Online, Inc., Community Leaders Litigation, 198 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Ski Train Fire In Kaprun, Austria, on November 11, 2000, 175 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2001) (choosing court that is choice of all plaintiffs and only 1 defendant opposes); In re Lutheran Brotherhood Variable Insurance Products Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 1999)), withdrawn from bound volume; In re Salomon Bros. Treasury Securities Litigation, 796 F. Supp. 1537 (J.P.M.L. 1992); In re Fire Disaster at Dupont Plaza Hotel, San Juan, Puerto Rico, on Dec. 31, 1986, 660 F. Supp. 982 (J.P.M.L. 1987); In re Longhorn Securities Litigation, 552 F. Supp. 1003, 1004–05 (J.P.M.L. 1982); In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 470 F. Supp. 855, 859 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Cutter Laboratories, Inc. “Braunwald-Cutter” Aortic Heart Valve Products Liability Litigation, 465 F. Supp. 1295, 1298 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re General Aircraft Corp. Antitrust/Tort Claims Act Litigation, 449 F. Supp. 604, 606 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Ascot Oils, Inc. Securities Litigation, 433 F. Supp. 1118, 1120 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Colocotronis Tanker Securities Litigation, 420 F. Supp. 998 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Olympia Brewing Co. Antitrust Litigation, 415 F. Supp. 398, 402 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Air Crash Disaster Near Collidge, Arizona, on May 6, 1971, 362 F. Supp. 572, 573 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Cessna Aircraft Distributorship Antitrust Litigation, 359 F. Supp. 543, 544 (J.P.M.L. 1973); In re Revenue Properties Co., 309 F. Supp. 1002, 1004 (J.P.M.L. 1970). Accord In re Air Crash Near Denver, Colo. on October 3, 1969, 339 F. Supp. 415, 416 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (no party contested Panel's proposed transferee district). But see In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 379 F. Supp. 989, 991 (J.P.M.L. 1974) (preference of parties not followed).
See, e.g., In re Capital Consultants, LLC, ERISA Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1385 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Westinghouse Elec. Corp. Uranium Contracts Litigation, 405 F. Supp. 316, 319 (J.P.M.L. 1975).
In re America Online Spin-Off Accounts Litigation, 310 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

In re Seroquel Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re TJX Companies, Inc., 505 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) Antitrust Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1384 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (favored or not opposed by most plaintiffs and all defendants); In re Isolagen, Inc., Securities & Derivative Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1366 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (nearly all parties favor or do not oppose district); In re Rhodia S.A., Securities Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Plastics Additives Antitrust Litigation (NO. II), 374 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re UICI “Ass'n Group” Ins. Litigation, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1360 (J.P.M.L. 2004). See also In re Helicopter Crash Near Wendle Creek, British Columbia on August 8, 2002, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1358 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Air Crash Near Denver, Colo. on October 3, 1969, 339 F. Supp. 415, 416 (J.P.M.L. 1972) (no party contested transferee district).

See, e.g., In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (support of most plaintiffs and some defendants); In re FieldTurf Artificial Turf Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 254 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (defendant and some plaintiffs support); In re FCA US LLC Monostable Electronic Gearshift Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (common defendant and majority of plaintiffs support chosen forum); In re Air Cargo Shipping Services Antitrust Litigation, 435 F. Supp. 2d 1342 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (support of numerous parties); In re Standard Automotive Corp. Retiree Benefits “ERISA” Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (preference of a majority of parties); In re Intel Corp. Microprocessor Antitrust Litigation, 403 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (near unanimous choice of parties); In re Publication Paper Antitrust Litigation, 346 F. Supp. 2d 1370 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer to district majority of plaintiffs and all defendants favored); In re Elevator and Escalator Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Carbon Black Antitrust Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003). See also In re General Motors Corp. Speedometer Products Liability Litigation, 530 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (noting defendants' “acquiescence” in choice of transferee district).
See, e.g., In re FEMA Trailer Formaldehyde Products Liability Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2007).

See, e.g., In re Abilify (Aripiprazole) Products Liability Litigation, 232 F. Supp. 3d 1342 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Atrium Medical Corp. C-Qur Mesh Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1355 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Viagra (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Battlefield Waste Disposal Litigation, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Vision Service Plan Tax Litigation, 484 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Sony BMG Audio Compact Disc Litigation, 429 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re American Honda Motor Co., Inc., Oil Filter Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Bank of America ATM Fee Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Sierra Wireless, Inc., Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re CP Ships Ltd. Securities Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Rivastigmine Patent Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 2d 1361 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re High Sulfur Content Gasoline Products Liability Litigation, 344 F. Supp. 2d 755 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Global Crossing Ltd. Securities Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Thaxton Group Inc. Securities Litigation, 323 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2004); cf. In re Vitamins Antitrust Class Actions, 1999 WL 1211449 (D.D.C. 1999) (venue decision by district court, not Panel); cf. In re Cessna 208 Series Aircraft Products Liability Litigation, 408 F. Supp. 2d 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (choice of all parties expressing a preference); but see In re Merscorp Inc., Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (parties' sipulation to a particular district overcome by judge's declining transfer due to heavy caseload).

See In re Uber Technologies, Inc., Data Security Breach Litigation, 304 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018); In re Dicamba Herbicides Litigation, 289 F. Supp. 3d 1345 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (support by several parties); In re: Sprouts Farmers Market, Inc., Employee Data Security Breach Litigation, 232 F. Supp. 3d 1348 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Taxotere (Docetaxel) Products Liability Litigation, 220 F. Supp. 3d 1360 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
See In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720 (J.P.M.L. 1976).

See, e.g., In re Helicopter Crash in Germany on September 26, 1975, 443 F. Supp. 447, 449 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Warhead Explosion Aboard USS Newport News on October 1, 1972, 411 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Palizzio, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Mack Truck, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 383 F. Supp. 503 (J.P.M.L. 1974); In re AMF Computerized Cash Register Contract Litigation, 360 F. Supp. 1404, 1405 (J.P.M.L. 1973).

In re Brown Co. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 307, 308 (J.P.M.L. 1971); see also In re Jetblue Airways Corp. Privacy Litigation, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (all responding parties support transfer to transferee district).
In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39, 40 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
In re American Family Mut. Ins. Co., 416 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2006).
In re Master Key, 320 F. Supp. 1404, 1406 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
In re Silicone Gel Breast Implants Products Liability Litigation, 793 F. Supp. 1098 (J.P.M.L. 1992).

See, e.g., In re: CTP Innovations, LLC, Patent Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1410 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Biomet M2a Magnum Hip Implant Products Liability Litigation, 896 F. Supp. 2d 1339 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2012) (also district where no action pending).
